Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hypothesis Testing of a Mediterranean-style Closure of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration: The generation and destruction of ocean basins on geologic timescales associated with Earth's plate tectonic system is a fundamental process that strongly influences climate patterns and ocean circulation, the location and timing of mountain building events, and the evolution and distribution of organisms. This project is testing the hypothesis that the Paleo-Tethys Ocean--an ancient ocean basin between Eurasia and Gondwana--closed in a tectonic style analogous to the modern ongoing closure of the western Mediterranean Sea. This hypothesis is motivated by the geographical proximity of ancient continent-continent collision zones within Asia to the geologic remnants of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean and the striking similarity of this tectonic assemblage to the modern western Mediterranean region. The Mediterranean-style model we are testing is counter to other tectonic models that suggest collisions between continents and high-pressure metamorphism of continental crust marks the demise of an ocean basin and the end of oceanic subduction. In contrast, the Mediterranean-style model involves the birth and rapid expansion of an ocean basin adjacent to the colliding continents. In addition to explicitly testing a Mediterranean-style closure of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean, alternative hypotheses will be implicitly tested in this project. Hypothesis testing will involve the structural and stratigraphic analysis of rocks in and around the Tibetan Plateau, and the determination of ages and geochemical compositions of individual minerals and rock samples. This project is a multi-disciplinary and collaborative research effort between faculty, researchers, and students at the University of Rochester and the West Virginia University along with scientists from the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research in the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean basins are fundamental to life on Earth. However, their shapes and relationships to adjacent continental landmasses have changed through time. These changes have far reaching effects including the diffusion of species and ocean-atmospheric circulation. The break-up and aggregation of continental fragments occurs through the generation and destruction of ocean basins. This process imparts lasting, but impermanent, changes to the physiography of continents. The tectonic style in which ocean basins close is inherently less well understood than our current understanding of how they open; the products of which are observable as mid-ocean spreading centers. The nature of how ocean basins close tends to be more cryptic in the geologic record.

This project tested the hypothesis that the Paleo-Tethys Ocean--an ancient ocean basin between Eurasia and Gondwana--closed about 200 million years ago in a tectonic style analogous to the modern ongoing closure of the western Mediterranean Sea. Closure of the Mediterranean Sea between Africa and Eurasia may be unique in terms of active global tectonics but this project suggests that it is anything but unique in the geologic record. The motivating hypothesis for this research was the geographical proximity of ancient continent-continent collision zones within Asia to the geologic remnants of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean and the striking similarity of this tectonic assemblage to the modern western Mediterranean region.

The mineral dating of samples and the analysis of sedimentary rocks were used to reconstruct the history of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean from the time that it began filling with large volumes of marine sediment until it closed and was tectonically incorporated into the Tibetan Plateau. This NSF project showed to a first order that the early history of the initial formation of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean was consistent with our understanding of the western Mediterranean Sea. We learned that the process of ocean subduction and rollback of ocean lithosphere during subduction lead to the opening of a new ocean basin in the case of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean rather than the more conventional idea of a remnant ocean basin resulting from only mantle upwelling, the rifting of two continental land masses, and little change in the position of the subduction boundary through time. This project also showed that enigmatic igneous rocks intruded into the marine sediments that filled the Paleo-Tethys ocean were formed from the melting continental crustal fragments. Like the western Mediterranean, this is consistent with the posit that the Paleo-Tethys Ocean basin was at least in part composed of attenuated continental crust that rifted away from Eurasia during the opening of a Mediterranean-style back-arc basin. The project was designed to explicitly test the Mediterranean-style model for the Paleo-Tethys Ocean while implicitly testing alternative models. This project found the simplest alternative tectonic models for the Paleo-Tethys to be invalidate for explaining the new observations that this project yielded and the complex architecture of the eastern Paleo-Tethys Ocean.

As for broader impacts, this project:  1) supported two graduate student researches that trained in geochemistry and geochronology; 2) engaged one undergraduate student in the mineral dating process; and 3) strengthened an international collaboration between U.S. institutions and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Project results were presented at two international conferences, five invited colloquium talks, and ten peer reviewed publications.
